fast3d.math

Class Camera

  • java.lang.Object
    • fast3d.math.Camera

  • public class Camera
extends java.lang.Object
    each shader needs information about the camera-setting to shade from, to project all the vertices correctly to the screen
    a camera has a position and an orientation (look-direction and up-direction) and a mode-setting
    Author:
    Tim Trense

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      CameraMode mode
      the cameras setting about how it looks into the universe

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Camera()
      position=Vector3d.zero
      lookDirection=Vector3d.forward
      mode=CameraMode.normalPerspectiveMode();

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void applyAspectRatioHpW(double heightPerWidth)
      scales the 3d virtual screen to the given aspect ratio at a normalized width and scaled height
      if used right this method is equal to applyAspectRatio(1d/heightPerWidth);
      it is preferred to use the width/height version because modern screens have a bigger width than height and if this method is used some of the bottom parts of the image are cut off (unless by using the other version some right parts of the image are cut off - on smartphones in portrait mode this method version is eventually the better choice)
      void applyAspectRatioWpH(double widthPerHeight)
      scales the 3d virtual screen to the given aspect ratio at a normalized height and scaled width

      sets focus to the specified target with zoom
      means look in direction towards the target

        public void moveInAbsoluteDirection(Vector3d dir)

        Parameters:

      • lookTo

        public void lookTo(Vector3d target,
                   Vector3d up)
        sets focus to the specified target with zoom=1d
        means look in direction towards the target
        Parameters:
        target - the vector to determine the direction to look along
        up - the vector to determine the z-rotation of the camera; may be just Vector3d.up() (if the camera doesn't look straight up or down that will work just fine)

      • lookTo

        public void lookTo(Vector3d target,
                   double zoom,
                   Vector3d up)
        sets focus to the specified target with zoom
        means look in direction towards the target
        a zoom-level under 0 means lookAway from target
        Parameters:
        target - the vector to determine the direction to look along
        up - the vector to determine the z-rotation of the camera; may be just Vector3d.up()
        zoom - positive value; the distance between camera position and virtual screen

      • lookInDirection

        public void lookInDirection(Vector3d dir,
                            Vector3d up)
        the up-vector should be orthogonal to the direction-vector, otherwise the shading may be warped
        Parameters:
        dir - the vector (starting from the cameras position) determining the relative position of the virtual screen to the cameras position
        up - the vector to determine the z-rotation of the camera; may be just Vector3d.up()

      • rot

        public void rot(Vector3d axis,
                double rad)
        rotates the look direction around the constant given axis
        Parameters:
        axis - the axe to rotate around in mathematically positive direction
        rad - the angle to rotate mathematically positive in radiant

      • applyAspectRatioWpH

        public void applyAspectRatioWpH(double widthPerHeight)
        scales the 3d virtual screen to the given aspect ratio at a normalized height and scaled width
        Parameters:
        widthPerHeight - the ratio of display width divided by display height

      • applyAspectRatioHpW

        public void applyAspectRatioHpW(double heightPerWidth)
        scales the 3d virtual screen to the given aspect ratio at a normalized width and scaled height
        if used right this method is equal to applyAspectRatio(1d/heightPerWidth);
        it is preferred to use the width/height version because modern screens have a bigger width than height and if this method is used some of the bottom parts of the image are cut off (unless by using the other version some right parts of the image are cut off - on smartphones in portrait mode this method version is eventually the better choice)
        Parameters:
        heightPerWidth - the ratio of display height divided by display width

      • getAspectRatioWpH

        public double getAspectRatioWpH()
        Returns:
        the current aspect ratio as width/height

      • getAspectRatioHpW

        public double getAspectRatioHpW()
        Returns:
        the current aspect ratio as height/width
